oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Vegetation in Danish field boundaries: A comparative study related to effects of agricultural practise
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Petersen, Sune
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Farming Systems
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Enrichment of biological diversity is often assumed to reflect good ecosystem integrity. Thus this variable has for some time been a key factor of management strategies and environmental programmes. The aim of the study presented here was primarily to observe, whether organic farming increases the biological diversity of field boundary vegetation when compared to conventional farming. Secondly, the aim was to consider, if increasing duration of the organic farming period also increases diversity. Finally, ecological interpretations of the data were given by comparing different agricultural practises in terms of general vegetation community patterns. The results documented that diversity of plant species was significantly higher within the organic field boundaries. Furthermore, there was a tendency towards higher diversity of plant species in the field boundaries that had been managed organically longest. Finally, analysis of community patterns revealed that Ruderal plant species are indicators of intensive or conventional farming. Altogether this study supports previous conclusions on low-intensive or organic farming as a method of enhancing the integrity of nature within the agricultural landscape.
oai_dc:dc.dc:identifier: Petersen, Sune (2003) Vegetation in Danish field boundaries: A comparative study related to effects of agricultural practise. [Submitted]
